form.official-title: To provide effective criminal prosecutions for certain identity thefts, and for other purposes.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Stopping Tax Offenders and Prosecuting Identity Theft Act of 2014
or the
STOP Identity Theft Act of 2014
.

section.header: Use of Department of Justice resources with regard to tax return identity theft

subsection.text: The Attorney General should make use of all existing resources of the Department of Justice, including any appropriate task forces, to bring more perpetrators of tax return identity theft to justice.

subsection.header: Considerations To be taken into account
subsection.text: In carrying out this section, the Attorney General should take into account the following:

paragraph.text: The need to concentrate efforts in those areas of the country where the crime is most frequently reported.
The need to coordinate with State and local authorities for the most efficient use of their laws and resources to prosecute and prevent the crime.
The need to protect vulnerable groups, such as veterans, seniors, and minors (especially foster children) from becoming victims or otherwise used in the offense.

section.header: Victims of identity theft may include organizations
section.text: Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: in subsection (a)(7), by inserting (including an organization) after another person; and
in subsection (d)(7), in the matter preceding subparagraph (A), by inserting or other person after specific individual; and

paragraph.text: in section 1028A(a)(1), by inserting (including an organization) after another person.

section.header: Identity theft for purposes of tax fraud
section.text: Section 1028(b)(3) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (B), by striking or at the end;
in subparagraph (C), by inserting or after the semicolon; and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: during and in relation to a felony under section 7206 or 7207 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986;

section.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Attorney General shall submit to the Committees on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and the Senate a report that contains the following information:

paragraph.text: Information readily available to the Department of Justice about trends in the incidence of tax return identity theft.
Recommendations on additional statutory tools that would aid in the effective prosecution of tax return identity theft.
The status on implementing the recommendations of the Department’s March 2010 Audit Report 10-21 entitled The Department of Justice’s Efforts to Combat Identity Theft.
